A. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



General [40 CFR 68.155]



The regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted to the EPA. 



The following areas are addressed in this summary:



(a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source;

(b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled;

(c) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps;

(d) The five-year accident history;

(e) The emergency response program; and,

(f)  Planned changes to improve safety.



(a) ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT THE STATIONARY SOURCE



Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) is committed to complying with all of the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program. Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.



Federal regulations require reporting when there is a release of ammonia exceeding 100 pounds in 24 hours.



State regulations require reporting when there is an accidental release of ammonia or a threat of accidental release of ammonia.  Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) interprets this regulation as any release that poses a threat of injury above and beyond minor irritation to anyone.



All releases and near misses are to be recorded using the incident investigation forms.  All releases are to be monitored and all readings recorded.  All releases and near misses are to be reviewed to develop procedu

res that may prevent future incidents.



Any release of more than 100 PPM may result in immediately shutting down the SCR ammonia system depending on the location of the release. The Duty Manager and the Project Manager are to be called if not on site for support.  Releases less than 50 PPM shall result in immediately calling the Duty Manager and the Project Manager, if not on site, for instructions.



The facility utilizes inspection procedures to review SCR process equipment on an ongoing basis.  These procedures identify potential sources of releases and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. Onsite technicians, registered engineers, SCR process experts, and certified process contractors review the equipment as required.



There are full time managers and operational employees such as technicians at this facility that have been trained to conduct visual and audible inspections of the ammonia systems on a regular basis. They are instructed to report any condition that could result in an ammonia release immediately.  An example would be excessive rust on piping or tanks. This team activity is the core of Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) prevention program.  



 (b) STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) facility at 73396 Tower Road, Boardman, OR., utilizes anhydrous ammonia for NOx emission reduction. Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a gas in its natural state and is extremely irritating to mucous membranes and lung tissue. The gas is pungent and may displace oxygen. Prolonged inhalation of high concentrations may cause bronchitis and or pneumonia, with some residual reduction in pulmonary functions. Repeat or prolonged contact of high concentrations of ammonia to the skin can cause frostbite, redness, pain, serious skin burn, and even death.  Safety Data Sheet's (SDS) are provided for anhydrous ammonia in the appendix. The SDS provides information on; toxicit

y, permissible exposure limits, physical data, reactivity data, corrosively data, thermal and chemical stability data, and the hazardous effects of mixing with other materials.



The facility will operate year round with the exception of no more than 30 to 60 consecutive days of down time depending on demand.



(c) THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



Key objectives of Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station)'s Prevention Program are briefly described below:



1) Maintain current and complete SCR process technical information. (Addressed under the Process Safety Information Element)



2) Provide thorough team evaluation of the SCR process.  The evaluation considers a number of potential problems including: mechanical problems, human errors, and external events (e.g., flooding, extreme weather, etc.).  All safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) management.  (Addressed under Process Hazard Analysis and Maintenance Elements.



3) Written procedures and policies that establish how the SCR process should be operated and maintained and how to investigate accidental releases. (Addressed under Operating Procedures, Maintenance, and Incident Investigation Elements.) 



4) Certification of process operators (technicians) to safely operate the SCR process. Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) certifies technicians following completion of Level I training and Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station)'s confirmation of the technician's ability to apply what they have learned.  (Addressed under Training Element.)



5) Employee involvement in the Prevention Program.  This is addressed on two levels.  First, SCR process operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the Prevention Programs (e.g., Process Hazard Analysis study team, writing and/or reviewing operating procedures, Incident

Investigation team, etc.).  This involvement encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities.  



Second, all Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) employees (direct hires and contract) at this facility receive ammonia awareness training.  Additionally, they have access to the RMP/PSM information.  These activities improve the overall safety of the employees. (Both levels are addressed under the Employee Participation and Training Elements)



6) Implementation of additional measures when changes are planned (procedural or mechanical).  These measures begin before any changes are made and may include a Process Hazard Analysis, operator training, and Process Safety Information updates plus other measures required by Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station)'s program.

 

If a mechanical change is required and for a change in maintenance contracts, Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) has a procedure for selecting a contractor based on the company's experience and safety history. Additionally, if welding, grinding, or other "Hot Work" occurs close to the refrigeration system, a Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) Hot Work permit is required.  The purpose of the permit and the associated Hot Work procedure is to minimize the possibility of a fire. 



7) Verification of Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station)'s compliance with the RMP/PSM program.  This third party audit process is an important tool to confirm whether each of the elements in the program have been implemented and properly documented by Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) personnel.  Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) established a Management System procedure to address any shortcomings, which the audit may find. (Addressed under Compliance Audit Element)   



8) Minimize employee injury and illness. (Addressed under Portland General Ele

ctric (Carty Generation Station)'s Safety and Health Procedure Program.



PREVENTION PROGRAM 



Process Safety Information

Process Safety Information includes a wide variety of books, manuals, and process information. These are available to employees that operate, maintain, or repair the process equipment or piping. There are three major categories of information: ammonia data such as SDS, safety information, first aid, chemical properties, safety bulletins, etc.; process information such as piping & instrumentation diagrams (P&ID's), block flow diagram, design codes and standards, pressure safety relief settings, safety system/devices, operating procedures, safe operating limits, and ramification of process deviation; and process equipment information such as equipment specifications, materials of construction, installation manuals, operating and maintenance manuals, and manufacturer's manuals.



See the Prevention Program PSI Tab 1 for the complete information

The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room.



Process Hazard Analysis

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed using the "What-if" checklist.  This addressed hazards, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, and a qualitative evaluation of the possible safety and health impact. The results of the PHA were prioritized and incorporated into a PHA Findings Report for follow-up as a corrective action log.



See Prevention Program Process Hazard Analysis Tab 2 for the complete guidelines

The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room. 



Operating Procedures and Technical Operating Specifications

The Technical Operating Specifications (TOS) made up of the process safety information and Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's) are provided for the process equipment.  Topics include general information such items as;



?    Objec

tives 

?    Special hazards 

?    Location 

?    Safety equipment needed 

?    P&ID's  and Block Flow Diagrams

?    Technical operating specifications, 

?    Step-by-step procedures

?    Specific warnings & PPE 



The SOPs cover different phases of operations such as: initial startup; normal, temporary and emergency operations; emergency shutdowns; and startup following a shutdown. Various other safety programs and procedures are included.



See the Prevention Program SOP Tab 3 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room.



Training 

All employees who are involved with anhydrous ammonia have been properly trained, at a minimum, in understanding the SDS, routine SCR process operation, emergency SCR process operation, emergency and normal safety practices, and the individual's role in the emergency response plan.



See the Prevention Program Training Tab 4 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room.



Mechanical Integrity and Maintenance

The purpose of the Maintenance and Mechanical Integrity program is to ensure that the equipment is maintained in good working condition.  Inspections, and ongoing maintenance based on industry standards or site history are performed on all process equipment including, pressure vessels, piping systems, relief/vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, pumps etc.



See the Prevention Program Mechanical Integrity Tab 5 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room.



Management of Change

The Management of Change (MOC) procedure requires that all changes (even "replacement in kind") be reviewed to see if there is a possible negative effect. The MOC review addresses the technical basis for the change, the impact on safety and health, modifications to operating procedures, and authorization requirements for the proposed c

hange.  Employees affected by the change are informed of the change before startup and trained in the proper procedures.



See the Prevention Program MOC Tab 6 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room.



Pre-Startup Review

Pre-startup safety reviews are required on all new or modified equipment/systems. This involves process safety information, process hazard analysis, training, safety procedures, operating procedures, and verification that construction and equipment are in accordance with the design specifications.



See the Prevention Program PSSR Tab 7 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room.



Compliance Audits

To insure that all the areas of the RMP/PSM program are followed, the company requires compliance audits.  At a minimum, these must be completed every three years.



See the Prevention Program Compliance Tab 8 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room.



Incident Investigation

An incident investigation shall be performed any time there is an incident which resulted in, or which could reasonably have resulted in, a significant release of ammonia. The purpose is to gain information that could prevent further accidents and to identify weaknesses in the emergency response plan that need to be addressed. Investigations are initiated promptly using a trained team. The findings and recommendations will be studied and appropriate corrective action taken.



See the Prevention Program Incident Investigation Tab 9 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room.



Employee Participation

The Employee Participation Program is an asset to both employees at the site and to the community as a whole.  As a general rule, employees who are fully involved have a greater sense of responsi

bility; they are more likely to catch the problems that can cause accidents. Employee awareness is for employees, not directly involved with the process, this includes knowing the hazards, the safety rules, warning signs, and evacuation procedures. All employees have access to the RMP/PSM Program. Involved employees participate directly in every phase of the program, including conducting the PHA, developing or reviewing operating procedures, reviewing incident investigations, and conducting mechanical integrity and compliance audits.



Community involvement is through coordination and cooperation with the local Fire department and the LEPC.



See the Prevention Program Employee Participation Tab 10 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room.



Hot Work and Safe Work Practices

This permit process is to protect against fire, explosion and other dangers resulting from hot work (welding and cutting outside the designated areas).  Hot work permits must be obtained before any work is done. The management reviews and issues the permits to insure all fire prevention and protection rules are met. Permits indicate the appropriate dates and the work to be done. The permits are kept on file until workers have completed the hot work operations.



See the Prevention Program Hot Work Tab 11 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room.



Contractors and Contractor Qualifications

This site follows strict guidelines for qualifying contractors who directly influence the safety of the process.  The contractor qualification procedure ensures that contractors and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers involved with the SCR process, that contractors understand their responsibility and train their people, and that a contractor's safety record is considered in reviewing the bids. 



See the Prevention Program Contractor Tab 12 f

or the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Control Room.



(d) FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There were no reportable ammonia releases at this facility during the last 5 years that meet the standard of State or Federal regulations. 

(e) EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This facility has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Response Plan developed for this facility for flammables, fire, earthquake, hazardous materials and other emergencies. 



Facility personnel have coordinated with responding outside agencies such as the Morrow County LEPC and the local Fire Department. The facilities emergency response plan has been coordinated with the community plan which includes these agencies. 



The facility has coordinated with outside parties through drills and tabletop exercises.  Facility personnel have exchanged data with local environmental authorities, fire and contractors who might assist during an emergency.  In addition, Fire Department personnel have toured the facility on several occasions to get a better understanding of the processes and the facility during an emergency such as fire, earthquake and/or a chemical release.



Plans have been developed to assist responding personnel.  All areas (zones) can reasonably be brought under control within 20 minutes of an ammonia emergency if personnel are on site.  Small releases can be brought under control immediately.  



The emergency release response plan for all releases is to gain access to the shutdown valves and switches.  If the system shut down areas are within the ammonia release area, the SCR process may be shut down if appropriate at the DCS control computer.  



Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) technicians are trained in the use of Self Contained Breathing Apparatus and ammonia specific, stationary and portable air monitoring equipment, decontamination, clean up and disposal.



The Federal Regulations considered while

developing this program include:

    EPA's Risk Management Plan

    OSHA's Emergency Action and Response Plan

    OSHA's Process Safety Standard

    EPA's Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know



PGE SAFETY AND HEALTH PROGRAM

This facility provides a safe and healthful workplace to their employees. As part of this commitment, Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) has an effective written Safety and Health Program. 

The written plan that covers the following elements is located in the control room:

     Management commitment/assignment of responsibilities 

     Safety communications system with employees 

     System for assuring employee compliance with safe work practices 

     Scheduled inspections/evaluation system 

     Accident investigation 

     Procedures for correcting unsafe/unhealthy conditions 

     Safety and health training and instruction 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

(f) PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Employee safety, community safety and the environment are primary concerns at this facility. The prevention program has been updated as a result.  Several PHA studies were conducted at Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) and the study team made recommendations for additional safety.



The following table includes scheduled improvements to reduce accidental releases. The recommendations are either in process or scheduled for completion in the near future.  



Planned Change

Test notification system prior to start up.

Add valve maintenance to your preventative maintenance and inspection program for all processes. Service valve stems and packing's.

Recommend at minimum once every three years.

Recommend installing ground level wind direction indicators during transfer visible at 2 to 8 feet at critical locations as wind direction socks do not reflect ground level flows.

Develop procedures for proper response based on Risk Assessment. Provide levels of exposure and define the proper PPE required based on the response

task and level of exposure. Define the difference between an emergency response and incidental release. Train personnel on same.

Purchase ammonia detection ( Hand Held Monitors) which provide levels to no less than 300 PPM for Ammonia

Perform additional table top and walk through drills on a regular basis. Pin-Point locations. Ask what if the leak occurs here? What is the proper response or procedure?

Request Boardman Fire District attend the annual site specific training.

Install removable or retractable barricade lines, straps or ropes at unloading.

Label all major components for quick response. Match to SOP and P&ID's. Add additional piping labels per industry standard recommendations.

Consider control of common area HVAC economizer intakes preventing contaminated intake air to occupied areas and electrical

components.

Verify and test critical interlock safeties at start up. High level, pressure, temperature, flow etc. Verify supply valve closure. Verify NH3

monitoring is functional and calibrated. Obtain written reports.

Raise the relief valve discharge outlet to 15' above a working platform and 20 feet from and window or door.

Perform PSM review meetings. Incorporate with staff meetings.

Develop written corrosion prevention program PSIG for exposed piping. PSIG to provide base template.
